title: Drought tour audition for the next generation of Coalition leaders
text:
At 43, Littleproud represents Maranoa, a seat his travelling colleague describes as "three times the size of Victoria".

Both are considered future leaders of their parties after Morrison and Nationals leader Michael McCormack leave the scene, likely still at least three years in the future.

Wearing tan Gazman chinos, black RM Williams boots and a cap from Casino Beef Week — described as NSW's premier beef event —Frydenberg was a long way from the leafy streets of Kooyong in eastern Melbourne.

He huddled with staffers discussing the government's commitments and absorbed information from farmers, businesspeople and local councillors.

After talking mental health and community pressures over a counter meal at the Australian Hotel in Inverell, Frydenberg sent his boss text messages late on Wednesday night.

An immediate report on what he was being told on the ground, the stories featured strength, struggle, suicide and the long wait for rain.

Littleproud was at home among his constituents, with many seeking him out through the three-day tour. While former Nationals leader Barnaby Joyce dominated events south of the border, Littleproud moved less obviously, rarely leaving without speaking to everyone in attendance.

The pair stopped at the rural fire depot in Stanthorpe on Thursday night, meeting the crews who responded to sprawling fires last month.

Advertisement

In failing sunlight, Sugarloaf Brigade first officer James Massey laughed with Littleproud as colleagues showed the Treasurer where the fire came over the hill nearby.

Massey gave an emphatic endorsement of the two men as as future leaders.

"Definitely, definitely, definitely," he said.

"When they talk to you as if you are a human being, not just paying you lip service, that makes hell of a difference.

"I think that's where reality comes into it, when we can shake each other's hands. I think the biggest thing they've got is they're in touch with everybody, with the average guy."

Outside Stanthorpe, the MPs met third-generation fruit grower Dino Rizzato on Friday. He's worked the land since the 1950s but his dam is so dry the soil has splits big enough to put your hand into.

Rizzato praised the federal government's response to the drought and explained the strategic downsizing of his tree stock to Frydenberg, himself not unfamiliar with the husbanding of resources.
description: In Josh Frydenberg and David Littleproud, farming communities might have just seen the future Liberal and Nationals leaders.
